Introduction

Bacterial tracheitis is a rare, potentially life-threatening bacterial infection of the trachea and surrounding structures that primarily affects children.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



In healthy individuals, the larynx (

figure 1
) is colonized with bacteria (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes) that can extend inferiorly to the trachea and become pathogenic under certain conditions.  In most cases of bacterial tracheitis, a predisposing viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI) causes tracheal mucosal injury; and viral URI symptoms (eg, cough) lead to microaspiration of upper respiratory secretions that introduce bacteria into the trachea.  The bacteria invade the injured tracheal mucosa and underlying soft tissues, leading to invasive polymicrobial infection.



Bacterial tracheitis is rare, and common risk factors include age <6 and recent tracheal mucosal injury (eg, viral URI, endotracheal intubation, tonsillectomy).

Clinical presentation



Bacterial tracheitis most commonly presents as a secondary bacterial infection.  Patients initially develop symptoms of a predisposing viral URI (eg, rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, cough).  As bacteria invade the injured tracheal mucosa, patients develop signs of worsening airway obstruction (eg, stridor, cough) that may rapidly progress to respiratory failure.  Stridor may be inspiratory or biphasic, and fever is common.  A productive cough may yield membranous exudates.



Less commonly, bacterial tracheitis presents as a primary bacterial infection in which patients develop signs of worsening airway obstruction at symptom onset.  Although rare, the infection can spread to the bronchial tree and lungs, causing pneumonia.



Less specific clinical findings related to local inflammation (eg, dysphagia, pharyngitis, voice changes) may also be present.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of bacterial tracheitis is clinical, and it should be suspected in patients with acute-onset, rapidly progressive airway obstruction preceded by viral URI symptoms.



Bacterial tracheitis should also be suspected when symptoms of croup (eg, inspiratory stridor, barking cough) do not improve with standard treatment (eg, racemic epinephrine, systemic glucocorticoids).



Direct visualization of purulent exudates and edema within the trachea via laryngoscopy and tracheobronchoscopy confirms the diagnosis.  The exudates are sent for microbiologic testing (eg, Gram stain, bacterial culture) to confirm the etiology.



Radiographic and laboratory findings that support the diagnosis include the following:



  • Radiographic findings are generally nonspecific and include subglottic tracheal narrowing (eg, steeple sign), which is also seen in croup (
    image 1
    ).  Bacterial exudates may be visualized as tracheal wall irregularities, a more specific finding when present.
  • Laboratory findings are also generally nonspecific and include elevated inflammatory markers; both leukopenia and leukocytosis may be seen.

Differential diagnosis



  • Croup (viral laryngotracheobronchitis) (
    figure 2
    ):  presents with barking cough and inspiratory stridor.  Bacterial tracheitis may occur as a complication of croup, but patients with bacterial tracheitis have acute-onset, rapidly progressive symptoms that do not improve with racemic epinephrine and systemic glucocorticoids.
  • Epiglottitis:  causes acute-onset, rapidly progressive upper airway obstruction, but, unlike in bacterial tracheitis, cough is not common in epiglottitis.  Patients often sit in the tripod position (
    figure 3
    ) with drooling and a muffled voice.  The inflamed epiglottis with thumb sign (
    image 2
    ) is visible on lateral neck radiograph, distinguishing the diagnosis.
  • Peritonsillar abscess (
    figure 4
    ) and retropharyngeal abscess (
    figure 5
    ):  cause airway obstruction that often presents with drooling, muffled voice, and stiff neck.  These symptoms are not common in patients with bacterial tracheitis.
  • Foreign body aspiration:  presents with acute-onset airway obstruction, but fever is not common.  Asymmetric breath sounds are typical, unlike in patients with bacterial tracheitis.  The foreign body may be visualized on imaging.

Management



Management of suspected bacterial tracheitis involves:



  • Airway management:  Patients with bacterial tracheitis are at high risk for complete airway obstruction due to the accumulation of bacterial exudates within the narrow tracheal lumen.  Airway management takes priority over diagnostic evaluation in patients with signs of progressive airway obstruction or respiratory failure.  Initial management may require endotracheal intubation or surgical placement of an artificial airway, particularly if there is severe subepiglottic edema.  Patients who do not require intubation at presentation should be monitored closely for signs of airway compromise.
  • Laryngoscopy and tracheobronchoscopy:  Direct visualization of the trachea via laryngoscopy and tracheobronchoscopy is diagnostic and therapeutic because it allows debridement of adherent exudates that cause airway obstruction.
  • Empiric antibiotic therapy:  Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy that targets the most common causal pathogens (eg, S aureus, S pyogenes, Haemophilus influenzae) should be initiated immediately (usually vancomycin plus a third-generation cephalosporin).  The antibiotic regimen should be adjusted according to bacterial culture results.
  • Supportive care:  Other supportive care measures (eg, oxygen, fluid resuscitation, antipyretics) are provided as needed.  Additional treatments (eg, systemic glucocorticoids, racemic epinephrine) may be considered.

Prognosis



With prompt recognition and appropriate management, the prognosis for bacterial tracheitis is generally favorable.  Most patients' condition improves clinically within 72 hours of initiation of antibiotic therapy.  Tracheal mucosa typically heals without scarring.  However, delayed diagnosis or inadequate treatment can result in death from complete airway obstruction or invasive infection.

Summary



Bacterial tracheitis is a rare, potentially life-threatening bacterial infection of the trachea and surrounding structures that primarily affects children.  Bacterial tracheitis presents with signs of airway obstruction (eg, stridor, cough) that may rapidly progress to complete obstruction and respiratory failure without prompt diagnosis, airway management, and empiric antibiotics.
